p: 39. The language of SZ. The language of this book is awkward and “inelegant” because it does not report about things but grasps being*. If we compare the ontological sections of Plato’s Parmenides or Aristotle’s Metaphysics VII with a narrative section of Thucydides, we can see the unprecedented formulations that Plato and Aristotle inflicted on the Greeks. Today our philosophical powers are weaker than theirs, and the ontological problems are more difficult for us than for the Greeks. Accordingly the complexity of our concept-formations and the severity of our expression will increase.
